sample.value:
a.	We conducted an a priori power analysis using G*Power using a rough-average of the observed effect sizes (d) in Study 1. Therefore, assuming a small-to-medium effect size (f = 0.18), alpha = .05, and 80% power, it was determined that 301 participants are necessary to sufficiently detect our interaction of interest. 
b.	Data collection will begin on 02/05/2020 and will continue until the end of the spring semester.

analyses.value:
a.	RQ1 two-way 3 (Type of fan) x 2 (Cost of ticket) ANOVA 
b.	RQ2 one-way ANOVA
c.	RQ3 one-way ANOVA

dependent.value:
a.	Trait rating perceptions (trustworthy, dedicated, loyal, honest, committed, honorable, genuine, compliant, striving, status-seeking, straightforward, kind, competent, organized, knowledgeable, positive/negative)
i.	Rated on a -3 to +3 bipolar scale.
b.	Identity fusion (Swann Jr., Gomez, Seyle, Morales, & Huici, 2009)
i.	Participants will rate the soccer fan on the extent to which his identity is fused with the soccer team before a soccer match, following a win, and following a loss. These ratings will be made using Swann’s identity fusion measure in which “fusion” is assessed by the overlap of two circles (one circle for the fan’s identity and one circle for his fandom for the team).
c.	Trust Game
i.	We will use a version of the Trust Game to assess how participants might choose to interact with the soccer fan. Participants were asked to imagine that we endowed them with $10. They were told that they could choose to keep all $10 and end the experiment, or they could choose to potentially double their money by giving money to the soccer fan and that we would double whatever amount of money they gave. Lastly, they were told that the soccer fan could decide to return some amount of money, and that they needed to trust that he would return at least some of it. Participants indicated their initial endowment using a sliding scale ranging from $0 to $10.

conditions.value: a.	Between-subjects design, 3 (Type of fan: SURF, BIRG, CORF) x 2 (Cost of ticket: Cheap, Expensive)

hypothesis.value:
a.	The tendencies to bask in reflected glory (BIRG; Cialdini et al., 1976) and cut off reflected failure (CORF; Snyder, Lassegard, & Ford, 1986) are well-documented and have been studied in many group-based domains (e.g., sports, politics); however, these two behaviors do not capture the entirety of possible responses to group success or failure. Here, we are investigating a third, previously unstudied behavior of individuals who continue to identify with and signal allegiance to their group despite the group’s failure. We call this type of behavior suffering under reflected failure (SURF). The present study will investigate how participants perceive someone who behaviors in one of these three ways. Additionally, we note similarities to SURFing-type behaviors in many other costly signals (e.g., Gintis, Smith, & Bowles, 2001; Dawkins & Krebs, 1978), behaviors that serve to signal one’s mate quality, social status, etc. despite potential “costs” to oneself (e.g., intentionally avoiding the benefits of BIRGing to one’s self-worth and self-esteem).   

b.	A preliminary study (N = 160) demonstrated that social perceivers evaluate a soccer fan differently depending on whether he was described as BIRGing, CORFing, or SURFing. After reading about and evaluating this person, participants completed a brief version of the Trust Game in which they were given a hypothetical endowment and told that they could (1) keep all of the money and end the experiment, or (2) double their money by giving some to the soccer fan. Lastly, they were told that the soccer fan could return some of the money they initially provided. Results indicated that the SURFer fan was given more money than the BIRGer and CORFer, although only the latter effect was statistically significant. Importantly, this endowment was most strongly mediated by perceptions of trustworthiness. Altogether, the present study seeks to extend this prior work. Participants will read one of six vignettes describing someone who BIRGs, CORFs, or SURFs after purchasing a cheap or expensive ticket to attend a soccer match.

c.	RQ1a: Is a sports fan that BIRGs, CORFs, or SURFs following a team win/loss (win for BIRG, loss for CORF and SURF) perceived differently? 
      i.        H1a: We hypothesize that the SURFer will be perceived as more trustworthy, dedicated, loyal, honest, committed, honorable, and genuine compared to the BIRGer and CORFer.
d.	RQ1b: Is a sports fan that BIRGs, CORFs, or SURFs following a team win/loss (win for BIRG, loss for CORF and SURF) perceived differently as a function of ticket price (cheap v. expensive)?
      i.	H1b: We hypothesize that the SURFer will be perceived as trustworthy, dedicated, loyal, honest, committed, honorable, and genuine compared to the BIRGer and CORFer, especially when he purchased an expensive ticket. 
e.	**We do not have predictions about the Cost of Ticket main effect.
f.	RQ2: Is a sports fan that BIRGs, CORFs, or SURFs following a team win/loss (win for BIRG, loss for CORF and SURF) perceived as having an identity that is differentially fused as a function of team performance?
      i.	H2: We hypothesize that the SURFer will be perceived as having greater identity fusion that the BIRGer and CORFer before a match and following a loss, but not following a win. No differences are hypothesized for this latter outcome. 
g.	RQ3: Is a sports fan that BIRGs, CORFs, or SURFs following a team win/loss (win for BIRG, loss for CORF and SURF) given a greater endowment in the Trust Game?
      i.	H3: We hypothesize that the SURFer will be given more money by participants in the Trust Game than the amount given to the BIRGer and CORFer. The amount given to the BIRGer and CORFer is not expected to differ.

attributes.title: Well-Being and Favourite Activities study (project code name: WILT)

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Well-Being and Favourite Activities Study (code name: WILT).

other.value:
As mentioned, this study is a replication of a pre-registered study (see https://osf.io/2e8rg).  Participants in this study will complete the same online survey that was administered to participants in MAGIC.  There are, however, two changes to the protocol:

1- Participants will be recruited using the 'representative sampling' feature on Prolific Academic (representative to the USA population), and 

2 - Participants will be excluded from analyses if they had also participated in the MAGIC study. (We anticipate that there will not be many instances of repeat participants.)

sample.value: Identical to the original MAGIC study (recruited n = 374). See https://osf.io/2e8rg

analyses.value: Identical to the original MAGIC study. See https://osf.io/2e8rg

outliers.value:
Identical to the original MAGIC study. Seehttps://osf.io/2e8rg.

In addition, there is a very small chance that participants in this study will have also participated in the MAGIC study. (Prolific Academic, the online service that is being used for recruitment, does not yet prevent specific users from participating in a study that uses the representative sampling feature.)  In the event that a participant in the current study also participated in MAGIC, they will be excluded.

dependent.value: These will be identical to those assessed in the original MAGIC study. See https://osf.io/2e8rg

conditions.value: There will be no random assignment in this study.

hypothesis.value:
The purpose of this study will be to replicate a study that we conducted called the "Favourite Activities and Well-Being Study" (project code name: MAGIC).  However, in this study we will recruit participants using representative sampling on Prolific Academic.  

We have already collected the data for MAGIC and have conducted some preliminary analyses.  However, we feel it is important to replicate the study with a representative sample.

The original MAGIC study was preregistered, available here: https://osf.io/2e8rg  

The MAGIC preregistration includes the hypotheses and other important details that will be identical for this study.

q1.value: Risk regulation processes in brand choice: Relationship power affects happiness from expressive and aspirational brands

q2.value: Peter Caprariello, Danielle Brick, Isabelle Oakland

q3.value:
In three pilot studies thus far we have found evidence that relationship-specific power changes the associations of different self-relevant brands with life satisfaction. In these three studies we have distinguished between aspirational brands (brands reflecting a person’s risky ideal-self) from expressive brands (brands reflecting a person’s comfortable present-self). We have found that thinking about aspirational brands is better for high-relationship-power consumers whereas thinking about expressive brands is better for low-relationship-power consumers (Pilot Studies A, B, and C). The effect disappears (Pilot Study B) or diminishes (Pilot Study C) when perceived partner judgments are removed. We interpret these findings using risk-regulation models of relationship security, in which insecurity (e.g., low relationship-power) is associated with need for partner approval when considering relationship-external growth or expansion.

The purpose of Study 1 (the study being pre-registered) is to replicate Pilot Study A, but replacing a forced-choice paradigm for considering brands with a manipulation of whether participants think about one brand over the other. In Pilot Study A, participants were introduced to aspirational and expressive brands and then were asked to choose one of the two brands. In Pilot Study B, we manipulated whether participants thought about one brand or the other. In both studies, aspirational brands were associated with higher life satisfaction for high-relationship-power participants than expressive brands, whereas expressive brands were associated with higher life satisfaction for low-relationship-power participants than aspirational brands. In Study 1, we would like to replicate this basic finding using the manipulation from Pilot Study B. In all other aspects, Study 1 will replicate Pilot Study A, which means that Study 1 will discard other features of Pilot Study B, such as a manipulation of partner approval.

Other differences between Pilot Study A and Study 1: 
- Pilot Study A measured pre-manipulation relationship-power using 4 items of the modified Anderson et al. (2012) 8-item measure. The remaining 4 items were measured post-manipulation, to test for within-person changes in relationship power. We did not observe changes in power as a result of our manipulation and therefore Study 1 will measure relationship power using all 8 items of the original scale, before the manipulation, discarding any test of pre-post changes in relationship power.
- Pilot Study A used a single-item measure of relationship power (in addition to the 4-item modified Anderson et al scale), which in hindsight better measured "who benefits from the relationship" than it measured relationship power per se. Study 1 will discard this measure in place of the 8-item modified Anderson et al scale (see note #1, above).
- Pilot Study A used early drafts of our definitions of aspirational and expressive brands. Study 1, in our manipulation of brand awareness, will utilize the most recent versions, which better reflect our conceptualizations of these brands. 
- Pilot Study A utilized a measure of relationship dependence as a DV, in addition to Satisfaction with Life (SWL). This measure will be discarded in Study 1, and we will measure only SWL as our sole DV, consistent with our model thus far.

q4.value:
1. Interaction Hypothesis:
Satisfaction with life scores will be predicted by the combination of relationship power and whether participants are thinking about aspirational brands or expressive brands.

2. Simple Effects Hypothesis:
At high levels of relationship power (defined as +1.5 SDs above the sample mean), aspirational brands will be associated with higher life satisfaction than expressive brands. At low levels of relationship power (-1.5 SDs), expressive brands will be associated with higher life satisfaction than aspirational brands. 

3. non-consequential main effects:
Although tangential to our model, we will also check for main effects of relationship power and of brand type on life satisfaction. Consistent with our studies thus far, we expect a positive and significant effect of power on life satisfaction. We expect a null association between brand type and life satisfaction: participants assigned to think about expressive brands should not, on average, report higher or lower life satisfaction than participants assigned to think about aspirational brands.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: The study will be a two-condition experiment, with one manipulated factor and continuous independent variable. We will manipulate brand type (aspirational brands versus expressive brands) and we will measure relationship power. The interaction of these two variables will be used to predict life satisfaction.

q9.value: Subjects will be randomly assigned to brand type condition. We will utilize Qualtrics for this purpose. All subjects will first provide examples of both kinds of brands (a within-subjects manipulation of brand types). Next, Qualtrics will randomly assign participants to imagine buying one brand or the other. This manipulation will be conducted between-subjects (visualizing one brand or the other).

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: The survey will be programmed into Qualtrics. The study will be posted to Prolific (https://www.prolific.co/). We would like to collect data from 431 participants, paying subjects $.55 each, which was the rate suggested to us by Prolific based on the amount of time it is expected to take participants to complete the study (~5 minutes). Subjects will be required to be in romantic relationships (Prolific screens for this inclusion criteria), although we will include an item in the study that measures this attribute, so that single participants can be excluded from later data analysis. We anticipate data collection to take one day to complete, and we expect hypothesis-testing to take approximately two weeks.

q13.value: We anticipate collecting data from 431 unique individuals. Our primary hypothesis will be analyzed between-subjects.

q14.value: We conducted a series of power analyses using G*Power's "ANCOVA: Fixed effects, main effects, and interactions" program from the "F tests" family of procedures. When we ran a nearly identical study as this, the effect size was equal to f = .135. If we expect an effect of the same size, with an alpha error probability of .05, and with anticipated power of .80, G*Power suggests a sample size of n = 431.

q15.value: Proflific will be programmed to cease collecting data after our sample size reaches 431 participants.

question.value: Brand type: We will be manipulating whether participants think about buying an aspirational brand or an expressive brand. Both brand types will be defined early in the study, and all participants will have listed one of each type prior to the manipulation. We will then manipulate brand type by having participants imagine buying themselves one of the two brands that they had listed earlier, randomly assigned.

We will measure relationship power as a predictor. We will be using Anderson et al's (2012) modified 8-item unidimensional scale to do this. 

We will measure satisfaction with life as an outcome (Diener et al., 2002). This is a 5-item scale consisting of one dimension, measuring perceived quality of life. 

We will also measure various demographic variables, including sex and age, although we do not have any hypotheses about the role of these variables and they are not central to our theoretical model.

data.name: FINAL COPY OF STUDY 1 - downloaded from Qualtrics.docx

extra.selectedFileName: FINAL COPY OF STUDY 1 - downloaded from Qualtrics.docx

question.value:
Relationship power will be created by averaging together all 8 items from the scale. 

Satisfaction with Life will be created by averaging together all 5 items from the scale.

We will be using a hierarchical multiple regression framework, to test for an interaction of relationship power (continuous) and brand type (categorical) on life satisfaction. This analysis will also include tests of main effects (for power and for brand type, on life satisfaction). We anticipate a main effect of power on life satisfaction, with life satisfaction correlating positively with relationship power. We do not anticipate a main effect of brand type on life satisfaction, as no main effect of this variable has shown up in any of our prior studies. We anticipate a significant 2-way interaction.

Following a significant interaction test, we will conduct a simple effects test of brand type on life satisfaction at 1.5 standard deviations above and below the mean of relationship power. The point of this test is to identify whether aspirational brands are preferred over expressive brands, at higher power, and whether the reverse preference holds at lower power.

Finally, we will conduct a Johnson-Neyman procedure to identify the point on the power continuum at which the relationship between brand type and life satisfaction switches from nonsignificant to statistically significant (at high levels of power) and the point on the power continuum at which the relationship between brand type and life satisfaction switches from statistically significant to nonsignificant (at low levels of power). This procedure is not statistically redundant with any of the planned procedures.

q20.value:
We do not anticipate needing to transform relationship power or life satisfaction. In prior studies we have conducted, both variables have been consistently normally distributed. If, for some reason, either variable shows signs of skew, we will transform the data to correct for this. We do not anticipate needing to do so.

Relationship power will need to be sample mean-centered prior to analysis, so that the interaction term is appropriately interpreted after controlling for main effects in hierarchical regression. 

Relationship power contains reverse-scored items, which will need to be re-coded prior to aggregating into composite variables. 

We will also code all the brands that participants list for luxuriousness and for familiarity, from the point of view of independent judges.

q21.value: We will use cut-off values of p less than .05, in two-tailed tests.

q22.value: Subjects will be required to be in romantic relationships to be eligible to participate. Prolific screens for this criteria but we will also include a question in our study probing for relationship status. If subjects indicate that they are single (e.g., if they broke up with their partner after registering on Prolific but before participating in our study), then their data will be excluded.

q23.value: Qualtrics will be programmed to require responses from all participants. Furthermore, the study is short and participants must complete the study in order to be compensated. Therefore, we anticipate that all subjects will provide responses to all variables, and we do not anticipate having to deal with missing data in this study.

q24.value: We may check for differences between male and female respondents, as an exploratory analysis. We may also see whether the relationships between our study variables differs as a function of age, as an exploratory analysis. One item will be included in the study as an attention check. We will examine whether attention check failures undermine our study's power (Maniaci & Rogge, 2014), at which point we may decide to compare results with and without subjects who failed the attention check. No other exploratory analyses are planned.

q25.value: This pre-registered study reflects accumulated decisions made over the course of three pilot studies which were run and analyzed prior to this. The initial idea was developed by Isabelle Oakland as a part of her senior honors thesis at Stony Brook University, and was presented at Stony Brook's URECA celebration in April, 2019. The focus of Isabelle's idea has shifted over time based on accumulating evidence. This pre-registered study reflects our primary focus of inquiry at this point in time.

If, for some reason, either variable shows signs of skew, we will transform the data to correct for this. We do not anticipate needing to do so.

Relationship power will need to be sample mean-centered prior to analysis, so that the interaction term is appropriately interpreted after controlling for main effects in hierarchical regression. 

Relationship power contains reverse-scored items, which will need to be re-coded prior to aggregating into composite variables. 

We will also code all the brands that participants list for luxuriousness and for familiarity, from the point of view of independent judges.
registration_responses.q21: We will use cut-off values of p less than .05, in two-tailed tests.
registration_responses.q22: Subjects will be required to be in romantic relationships to be eligible to participate. Prolific screens for this criteria but we will also include a question in our study probing for relationship status. If subjects indicate that they are single (e.g., if they broke up with their partner after registering on Prolific but before participating in our study), then their data will be excluded.
registration_responses.q23: Qualtrics will be programmed to require responses from all participants. Furthermore, the study is short and participants must complete the study in order to be compensated. Therefore, we anticipate that all subjects will provide responses to all variables, and we do not anticipate having to deal with missing data in this study.
registration_responses.q24: We may check for differences between male and female respondents, as an exploratory analysis. We may also see whether the relationships between our study variables differs as a function of age, as an exploratory analysis. One item will be included in the study as an attention check. We will examine whether attention check failures undermine our study's power (Maniaci & Rogge, 2014), at which point we may decide to compare results with and without subjects who failed the attention check. No other exploratory analyses are planned.
registration_responses.q25: This pre-registered study reflects accumulated decisions made over the course of three pilot studies which were run and analyzed prior to this. The initial idea was developed by Isabelle Oakland as a part of her senior honors thesis at Stony Brook University, and was presented at Stony Brook's URECA celebration in April, 2019. The focus of Isabelle's idea has shifted over time based on accumulating evidence. This pre-registered study reflects our primary focus of inquiry at this point in time.
registration_responses.q8.question: The study will be a two-condition experiment, with one manipulated factor and continuous independent variable. We will manipulate brand type (aspirational brands versus expressive brands) and we will measure relationship power. The interaction of these two variables will be used to predict life satisfaction.
registration_responses.q12.question: The survey will be programmed into Qualtrics. The study will be posted to Prolific (https://www.prolific.co/). We would like to collect data from 431 participants, paying subjects $.55 each, which was the rate suggested to us by Prolific based on the amount of time it is expected to take participants to complete the study (~5 minutes). Subjects will be required to be in romantic relationships (Prolific screens for this inclusion criteria), although we will include an item in the study that measures this attribute, so that single participants can be excluded from later data analysis. We anticipate data collection to take one day to complete, and we expect hypothesis-testing to take approximately two weeks.
registration_responses.q16.question: Brand type: We will be manipulating whether participants think about buying an aspirational brand or an expressive brand. Both brand types will be defined early in the study, and all participants will have listed one of each type prior to the manipulation. We will then manipulate brand type by having participants imagine buying themselves one of the two brands that they had listed earlier, randomly assigned.
registration_responses.q17.question:
We will measure relationship power as a predictor. We will be using Anderson et al's (2012) modified 8-item unidimensional scale to do this. 

We will measure satisfaction with life as an outcome (Diener et al., 2002). This is a 5-item scale consisting of one dimension, measuring perceived quality of life. 

We will also measure various demographic variables, including sex and age, although we do not have any hypotheses about the role of these variables and they are not central to our theoretical model.

registration_responses.q18.question:
Relationship power will be created by averaging together all 8 items from the scale. 

Satisfaction with Life will be created by averaging together all 5 items from the scale.
registration_responses.q19.question:
We will be using a hierarchical multiple regression framework, to test for an interaction of relationship power (continuous) and brand type (categorical) on life satisfaction. This analysis will also include tests of main effects (for power and for brand type, on life satisfaction). We anticipate a main effect of power on life satisfaction, with life satisfaction correlating positively with relationship power. We do not anticipate a main effect of brand type on life satisfaction, as no main effect of this variable has shown up in any of our prior studies. We anticipate a significant 2-way interaction.

Following a significant interaction test, we will conduct a simple effects test of brand type on life satisfaction at 1.5 standard deviations above and below the mean of relationship power. The point of this test is to identify whether aspirational brands are preferred over expressive brands, at higher power, and whether the reverse preference holds at lower power.

Finally, we will conduct a Johnson-Neyman procedure to identify the point on the power continuum at which the relationship between brand type and life satisfaction switches from nonsignificant to statistically significant (at high levels of power) and the point on the power continuum at which the relationship between brand type and life satisfaction switches from statistically significant to nonsignificant (at low levels of power). This procedure is not statistically redundant with any of the planned procedures.

q1.value: Risk regulation processes in brand choice: Relationship power affects happiness from expressive and aspirational brands

q2.value: Peter Caprariello, Danielle Brick, Isabelle Oakland

q3.value:
In three pilot studies thus far we have found evidence that relationship-specific power changes the associations of different self-relevant brands with life satisfaction. In these three studies we have distinguished between aspirational brands (brands reflecting a person’s risky ideal-self) from expressive brands (brands reflecting a person’s comfortable present-self). We have found that thinking about aspirational brands is better for high-relationship-power consumers whereas thinking about expressive brands is better for low-relationship-power consumers (Pilot Studies A, B, and C). The effect disappears (Pilot Study B) or diminishes (Pilot Study C) when perceived partner judgments are removed. We interpret these findings using risk-regulation models of relationship security, in which insecurity (e.g., low relationship-power) is associated with need for partner approval when considering relationship-external growth or expansion.

The purpose of Study 1 (the study being pre-registered) is to replicate Pilot Study A, but replacing a forced-choice paradigm for considering brands with a manipulation of whether participants think about one brand over the other. In Pilot Study A, participants were introduced to aspirational and expressive brands and then were asked to choose one of the two brands. In Pilot Study B, we manipulated whether participants thought about one brand or the other. In both studies, aspirational brands were associated with higher life satisfaction for high-relationship-power participants than expressive brands, whereas expressive brands were associated with higher life satisfaction for low-relationship-power participants than aspirational brands. In Study 1, we would like to replicate this basic finding using the manipulation from Pilot Study B. In all other aspects, Study 1 will replicate Pilot Study A, which means that Study 1 will discard other features of Pilot Study B, such as a manipulation of partner approval.

Other differences between Pilot Study A and Study 1: 
- Pilot Study A measured pre-manipulation relationship-power using 4 items of the modified Anderson et al. (2012) 8-item measure. The remaining 4 items were measured post-manipulation, to test for within-person changes in relationship power. We did not observe changes in power as a result of our manipulation and therefore Study 1 will measure relationship power using all 8 items of the original scale, before the manipulation, discarding any test of pre-post changes in relationship power.
- Pilot Study A used a single-item measure of relationship power (in addition to the 4-item modified Anderson et al scale), which in hindsight better measured "who benefits from the relationship" than it measured relationship power per se. Study 1 will discard this measure in place of the 8-item modified Anderson et al scale (see note #1, above).
- Pilot Study A used early drafts of our definitions of aspirational and expressive brands. Study 1, in our manipulation of brand awareness, will utilize the most recent versions, which better reflect our conceptualizations of these brands. 
- Pilot Study A utilized a measure of relationship dependence as a DV, in addition to Satisfaction with Life (SWL). This measure will be discarded in Study 1, and we will measure only SWL as our sole DV, consistent with our model thus far.

q4.value:
1. Interaction Hypothesis:
Satisfaction with life scores will be predicted by the combination of relationship power and whether participants are thinking about aspirational brands or expressive brands.

2. Simple Effects Hypothesis:
At high levels of relationship power (defined as +1.5 SDs above the sample mean), aspirational brands will be associated with higher life satisfaction than expressive brands. At low levels of relationship power (-1.5 SDs), expressive brands will be associated with higher life satisfaction than aspirational brands. 

3. non-consequential main effects:
Although tangential to our model, we will also check for main effects of relationship power and of brand type on life satisfaction. Consistent with our studies thus far, we expect a positive and significant effect of power on life satisfaction. We expect a null association between brand type and life satisfaction: participants assigned to think about expressive brands should not, on average, report higher or lower life satisfaction than participants assigned to think about aspirational brands.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

q9.value: Subjects will be randomly assigned to brand type condition. We will utilize Qualtrics for this purpose. All subjects will first provide examples of both kinds of brands (a within-subjects manipulation of brand types). Next, Qualtrics will randomly assign participants to imagine buying one brand or the other. This manipulation will be conducted between-subjects (visualizing one brand or the other).

We anticipate data collection to take one day to complete, and we expect hypothesis-testing to take approximately two weeks.

q13.value: We anticipate collecting data from 431 unique individuals. Our primary hypothesis will be analyzed between-subjects.

q14.value: We conducted a series of power analyses using G*Power's "ANCOVA: Fixed effects, main effects, and interactions" program from the "F tests" family of procedures. When we ran a nearly identical study as this, the effect size was equal to f = .135. If we expect an effect of the same size, with an alpha error probability of .05, and with anticipated power of .80, G*Power suggests a sample size of n = 431.

q15.value: Proflific will be programmed to cease collecting data after our sample size reaches 431 participants.

question.value: Brand type: We will be manipulating whether participants think about buying an aspirational brand or an expressive brand. question.value:
Relationship power will be created by averaging together all 8 items from the scale. 

Satisfaction with Life will be created by averaging together all 5 items from the scale.

We will be using a hierarchical multiple regression framework, to test for an interaction of relationship power (continuous) and brand type (categorical) on life satisfaction. This analysis will also include tests of main effects (for power and for brand type, on life satisfaction). We anticipate a main effect of power on life satisfaction, with life satisfaction correlating positively with relationship power. We do not anticipate a main effect of brand type on life satisfaction, as no main effect of this variable has shown up in any of our prior studies. We anticipate a significant 2-way interaction.

Following a significant interaction test, we will conduct a simple effects test of brand type on life satisfaction at 1.5 standard deviations above and below the mean of relationship power. The point of this test is to identify whether aspirational brands are preferred over expressive brands, at higher power, and whether the reverse preference holds at lower power.

Finally, we will conduct a Johnson-Neyman procedure to identify the point on the power continuum at which the relationship between brand type and life satisfaction switches from nonsignificant to statistically significant (at high levels of power) and the point on the power continuum at which the relationship between brand type and life satisfaction switches from statistically significant to nonsignificant (at low levels of power). This procedure is not statistically redundant with any of the planned procedures.

q20.value:
We do not anticipate needing to transform relationship power or life satisfaction. In prior studies we have conducted, both variables have been consistently normally distributed. If, for some reason, either variable shows signs of skew, we will transform the data to correct for this. We do not anticipate needing to do so.

Relationship power will need to be sample mean-centered prior to analysis, so that the interaction term is appropriately interpreted after controlling for main effects in hierarchical regression. 

Relationship power contains reverse-scored items, which will need to be re-coded prior to aggregating into composite variables. 

We will also code all the brands that participants list for luxuriousness and for familiarity, from the point of view of independent judges.

q21.value: We will use cut-off values of p less than .05, in two-tailed tests.

q22.value: Subjects will be required to be in romantic relationships to be eligible to participate. Prolific screens for this criteria but we will also include a question in our study probing for relationship status. If subjects indicate that they are single (e.g., if they broke up with their partner after registering on Prolific but before participating in our study), then their data will be excluded.

q23.value: Qualtrics will be programmed to require responses from all participants. Furthermore, the study is short and participants must complete the study in order to be compensated. Therefore, we anticipate that all subjects will provide responses to all variables, and we do not anticipate having to deal with missing data in this study.

q24.value: We may check for differences between male and female respondents, as an exploratory analysis. We may also see whether the relationships between our study variables differs as a function of age, as an exploratory analysis. One item will be included in the study as an attention check. We will examine whether attention check failures undermine our study's power (Maniaci & Rogge, 2014), at which point we may decide to compare results with and without subjects who failed the attention check. No other exploratory analyses are planned.

q25.value: This pre-registered study reflects accumulated decisions made over the course of three pilot studies which were run and analyzed prior to this. The initial idea was developed by Isabelle Oakland as a part of her senior honors thesis at Stony Brook University, and was presented at Stony Brook's URECA celebration in April, 2019. The focus of Isabelle's idea has shifted over time based on accumulating evidence. This pre-registered study reflects our primary focus of inquiry at this point in time.

registration_responses.q3:
In three pilot studies thus far we have found evidence that relationship-specific power changes the associations of different self-relevant brands with life satisfaction. In these three studies we have distinguished between aspirational brands (brands reflecting a person’s risky ideal-self) from expressive brands (brands reflecting a person’s comfortable present-self). We have found that thinking about aspirational brands is better for high-relationship-power consumers whereas thinking about expressive brands is better for low-relationship-power consumers (Pilot Studies A, B, and C). The effect disappears (Pilot Study B) or diminishes (Pilot Study C) when perceived partner judgments are removed. We interpret these findings using risk-regulation models of relationship security, in which insecurity (e.g., low relationship-power) is associated with need for partner approval when considering relationship-external growth or expansion.

The purpose of Study 1 (the study being pre-registered) is to replicate Pilot Study A, but replacing a forced-choice paradigm for considering brands with a manipulation of whether participants think about one brand over the other. In Pilot Study A, participants were introduced to aspirational and expressive brands and then were asked to choose one of the two brands. In Pilot Study B, we manipulated whether participants thought about one brand or the other. In both studies, aspirational brands were associated with higher life satisfaction for high-relationship-power participants than expressive brands, whereas expressive brands were associated with higher life satisfaction for low-relationship-power participants than aspirational brands. In Study 1, we would like to replicate this basic finding using the manipulation from Pilot Study B. In all other aspects, Study 1 will replicate Pilot Study A, which means that Study 1 will discard other features of Pilot Study B, such as a manipulation of partner approval.

Other differences between Pilot Study A and Study 1: 
- Pilot Study A measured pre-manipulation relationship-power using 4 items of the modified Anderson et al. (2012) 8-item measure. The remaining 4 items were measured post-manipulation, to test for within-person changes in relationship power. We did not observe changes in power as a result of our manipulation and therefore Study 1 will measure relationship power using all 8 items of the original scale, before the manipulation, discarding any test of pre-post changes in relationship power.
- Pilot Study A used a single-item measure of relationship power (in addition to the 4-item modified Anderson et al scale), which in hindsight better measured "who benefits from the relationship" than it measured relationship power per se. Study 1 will discard this measure in place of the 8-item modified Anderson et al scale (see note #1, above).
- Pilot Study A used early drafts of our definitions of aspirational and expressive brands. Study 1, in our manipulation of brand awareness, will utilize the most recent versions, which better reflect our conceptualizations of these brands. 
- Pilot Study A utilized a measure of relationship dependence as a DV, in addition to Satisfaction with Life (SWL). This measure will be discarded in Study 1, and we will measure only SWL as our sole DV, consistent with our model thus far.

At low levels of relationship power (-1.5 SDs), expressive brands will be associated with higher life satisfaction than aspirational brands.

We expect a null association between brand type and life satisfaction: participants assigned to think about expressive brands should not, on average, report higher or lower life satisfaction than participants assigned to think about aspirational brands.

attributes.title: Relationship risk regulation, brand choice, and happiness
attributes.description:
This is a collaboration between Peter Caprariello, Danielle Brick, and Isabelle Oakland. The idea began as Isabelle Oakland's senior honors thesis at Stony Brook University, developed in the fall of 2018. At the time of this writing, three studies have been conducted, and selected results from these three studies have been presented at Stony Brook's Undergraduate Research Symposium (URECA; spring 2019) and have been submitted to the Society for Consumer Psychology's (SCP) 2020 conference as a poster. 

In these three studies we found evidence that relationship-specific power changes the associations of different self-relevant brands with life satisfaction. We distinguished aspirational brands (reflecting a person’s ideal-self) from expressive brands (reflecting a person’s present-self) and found that thinking about aspirational brands is better for high-relationship-power consumers whereas thinking about expressive brands is better for low-relationship-power consumers. The effect disappears when perceived partner judgments are removed. We interpreted these findings using risk-regulation models of relationship security, in which insecurity (e.g., low relationship-power) is associated with need for partner approval when considering relationship-external growth or expansion.

We have chosen to pre-register our hypotheses and intended procedures for a fourth study. The goal of the fourth study is to replicate the basic idea, but removing some internal weaknesses and old ideas that we no longer endorse.

registration_responses.q13: We anticipate collecting data from 431 unique individuals. Our primary hypothesis will be analyzed between-subjects.
registration_responses.q14: We conducted a series of power analyses using G*Power's "ANCOVA: Fixed effects, main effects, and interactions" program from the "F tests" family of procedures. When we ran a nearly identical study as this, the effect size was equal to f = .135. If we expect an effect of the same size, with an alpha error probability of .05, and with anticipated power of .80, G*Power suggests a sample size of n = 431.
registration_responses.q15: Proflific will be programmed to cease collecting data after our sample size reaches 431 participants.
registration_responses.q20:
We do not anticipate needing to transform relationship power or life satisfaction. In prior studies we have conducted, both variables have been consistently normally distributed. If, for some reason, either variable shows signs of skew, we will transform the data to correct for this. We do not anticipate needing to do so.

Relationship power will need to be sample mean-centered prior to analysis, so that the interaction term is appropriately interpreted after controlling for main effects in hierarchical regression. 

Relationship power contains reverse-scored items, which will need to be re-coded prior to aggregating into composite variables. 

We will also code all the brands that participants list for luxuriousness and for familiarity, from the point of view of independent judges.
registration_responses.q21: We will use cut-off values of p less than .05, in two-tailed tests.
registration_responses.q22: Subjects will be required to be in romantic relationships to be eligible to participate. Prolific screens for this criteria but we will also include a question in our study probing for relationship status. If subjects indicate that they are single (e.g., if they broke up with their partner after registering on Prolific but before participating in our study), then their data will be excluded.
registration_responses.q23: Qualtrics will be programmed to require responses from all participants. Furthermore, the study is short and participants must complete the study in order to be compensated. Therefore, we anticipate that all subjects will provide responses to all variables, and we do not anticipate having to deal with missing data in this study.
registration_responses.q24: We may check for differences between male and female respondents, as an exploratory analysis. We may also see whether the relationships between our study variables differs as a function of age, as an exploratory analysis. One item will be included in the study as an attention check. We will examine whether attention check failures undermine our study's power (Maniaci & Rogge, 2014), at which point we may decide to compare results with and without subjects who failed the attention check. No other exploratory analyses are planned.
registration_responses.q25: This pre-registered study reflects accumulated decisions made over the course of three pilot studies which were run and analyzed prior to this. The initial idea was developed by Isabelle Oakland as a part of her senior honors thesis at Stony Brook University, and was presented at Stony Brook's URECA celebration in April, 2019. The focus of Isabelle's idea has shifted over time based on accumulating evidence. This pre-registered study reflects our primary focus of inquiry at this point in time.
registration_responses.q8.question: The study will be a two-condition experiment, with one manipulated factor and continuous independent variable. We will manipulate brand type (aspirational brands versus expressive brands) and we will measure relationship power. The interaction of these two variables will be used to predict life satisfaction.
registration_responses.q12.question: The survey will be programmed into Qualtrics. The study will be posted to Prolific (https://www.prolific.co/). We would like to collect data from 431 participants, paying subjects $.55 each, which was the rate suggested to us by Prolific based on the amount of time it is expected to take participants to complete the study (~5 minutes). Subjects will be required to be in romantic relationships (Prolific screens for this inclusion criteria), although we will include an item in the study that measures this attribute, so that single participants can be excluded from later data analysis. We anticipate data collection to take one day to complete, and we expect hypothesis-testing to take approximately two weeks.
registration_responses.q16.question: Brand type: We will be manipulating whether participants think about buying an aspirational brand or an expressive brand. Both brand types will be defined early in the study, and all participants will have listed one of each type prior to the manipulation. We will then manipulate brand type by having participants imagine buying themselves one of the two brands that they had listed earlier, randomly assigned.
registration_responses.q17.question:
We will measure relationship power as a predictor. We will be using Anderson et al's (2012) modified 8-item unidimensional scale to do this. 

We will measure satisfaction with life as an outcome (Diener et al., 2002). This is a 5-item scale consisting of one dimension, measuring perceived quality of life. 

We will also measure various demographic variables, including sex and age, although we do not have any hypotheses about the role of these variables and they are not central to our theoretical model.

q17.uploader.file_name: FINAL COPY OF STUDY 1 - downloaded from Qualtrics.docx

registration_responses.q18.question:
Relationship power will be created by averaging together all 8 items from the scale. 

Satisfaction with Life will be created by averaging together all 5 items from the scale.
registration_responses.q19.question:
We will be using a hierarchical multiple regression framework, to test for an interaction of relationship power (continuous) and brand type (categorical) on life satisfaction. This analysis will also include tests of main effects (for power and for brand type, on life satisfaction). We anticipate a main effect of power on life satisfaction, with life satisfaction correlating positively with relationship power. We do not anticipate a main effect of brand type on life satisfaction, as no main effect of this variable has shown up in any of our prior studies. We anticipate a significant 2-way interaction.

Following a significant interaction test, we will conduct a simple effects test of brand type on life satisfaction at 1.5 standard deviations above and below the mean of relationship power. The point of this test is to identify whether aspirational brands are preferred over expressive brands, at higher power, and whether the reverse preference holds at lower power.

Finally, we will conduct a Johnson-Neyman procedure to identify the point on the power continuum at which the relationship between brand type and life satisfaction switches from nonsignificant to statistically significant (at high levels of power) and the point on the power continuum at which the relationship between brand type and life satisfaction switches from statistically significant to nonsignificant (at low levels of power). This procedure is not statistically redundant with any of the planned procedures.

attributes.title: Systematic review of electronic cigarette marketing communication: Strategies, messages, and communication channels

q1.value: Protocol for systematic review of electronic cigarette marketing communication: Strategies, messages, and communication channels

q2.value: Joanne Chen Lyu, Di Wang, Peiyi Huang, Pamela M. Ling

q3.value: Despite the heated debate over the health effects of e-cigarettes, the e-cigarette market has continued to increase rapidly. Various novel forms of marketing communication undertaken by the e-cigarette industry play an important role in the expansion of the e-cigarette market. This study will provide a descriptive analysis of e-cigarette marketing strategies, messages, and communication channels in order to facilitate in-depth understanding of marketing communication used by the e-cigarette companies/industry.  The results are relevant to inform policy makers efforts to formulate policies that can effectively deter youth initiation or that counter misperceptions resulting from industry marketing communication.

q4.value:
This is a descriptive analysis. No hypotheses were put forth, instead we will address the following questions:
Key Question 1: What marketing strategies are used by the e-cigarette industry?
Key Question 2: What are the messages in the marketing strategies?
Key Question 3: Through what communication channels are marketing strategies delivered to the public?
Key Question 4: How have the marketing strategies, messages, and communication channels interacted with each other?

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: A systematic review

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

q11.value: All published English academic articles acquired through the search procedure that is elaborated in the data collection procedures section of the registration and meeting the inclusion criteria will be included in this study. Search in databases, and title and abstract screening have been done. Full-text screening is ongoing.

question.value:
We developed search strings with librarians to search in PubMed, EMBASE, Web of Science, PsycInfo, CINAHL, Social Services Abstracts, Sociological Abstracts, Business Source Complete, and Communication & Mass Media Complete.

Take PubMed for instance, the search string is: (e-cigarette OR e-cigarettes OR "electronic cigarette" OR "electronic cigarettes" OR "Electronic Nicotine Delivery Systems"[Mesh] OR vaping OR "Vaping"[Mesh]) AND (marketing OR "marketing"[mesh] OR "Advertising as Topic"[Mesh] OR advertise OR advertising OR advertisement OR promotion OR promoting OR brand OR branding OR "Public Relations"[Mesh] OR "public relations" OR “PR” OR sponsorship OR "corporate social responsibility") AND ("social media" OR "social media"[Mesh] OR magazine OR newspaper OR television OR radio OR facebook OR twitter OR instagram OR youTube OR internet OR "Internet"[mesh] OR google OR apps OR "Smartphone"[Mesh] OR smartphone OR “point-of-sale”)

Studies are limited to studies in English published in academic journals from 2003, when e-cigarettes were first invented, to present. There is no restriction on research methods and research design. Both quantitative studies and qualitative studies are included in the study.

Inclusion criteria:
To be included, the study must simultaneously focus on e-cigarettes and at least one type of marketing communication examined by this study, including marketing, advertising, promotion, branding, public relations, sponsorship, corporate social responsibility. Examination of messages in any type(s) of the above-mentioned marketing communication must be (one of) the focus of the study. In addition, the examined marketing strategies must be originated by e-cigarette companies/industry, rather than e-cigarette users, governmental institutions such as FDA, or NGO etc.

Exclusion criteria:
Grey literature including dissertations, conference proceeding papers, abstracts, or editorials, commentaries will be excluded. Studies that only examined the effect of e-cigarettes or the relationship between marketing communication and the use of e-cigarettes without focusing on messages in any type(s) of the above-mentioned marketing communication will be excluded. Marketing strategies not conducted by the e-cigarette companies/industry will be excluded.

All references obtained through the search of the databases PubMed, EMBASE, Web of Science, PsycInfo, CINAHL, Social Services Abstracts, Sociological Abstracts, Business Source Complete, and Communication & Mass Media Complete, will be imported into Covidence, an online software platform that streamlines the procedures of systematic reviews. In the step of importing references, Covidence can automatically identifies duplicate references, and one of the investigators manually confirmed whether they are true duplicates or not. In the next step, Covidence enables two reviewers to independently screen titles and abstracts. They use the predetermined criteria to vote yes, no or maybe in Covidence to make judgement about whether an article should be included for full text review. Any disagreements will be resolved through discussion or involvement of a third reviewer when necessary.

For each article, the following information will be extracted:
author name,
article title, 
year of publication, 
journal name, 
study country/region
marketing strategy type,
messages delivered in the marketing strategy,
communication channel,
sender/user of the marketing strategy
target audience (youth or adults),
research method.

The coding guidelines have been developed iteratively by reading relevant literature and the articles included into this study. Information of the first ten articles included for full text review in Covidence will be extracted manually using the predetermined coding guideline to test applicability, and the need for new codes. The code book will be revised and re-tested with additional sample articles until the two reviewers achieve consensus on the coding book's applicability and no need for more new codes.

q13.value: No limits on the sample size. All published English academic articles acquired through the above-mentioned search procedure and meeting the inclusion criteria will be included in this study.

question.value: Not applicable
marketing strategies, messages, and communication channels
This is a descriptive analysis. For the quantitative part of the study, frequency and percentage will be provided to describe the data.

q24.value:
PRISMA flow diagram will be used to present the results of search and screening, indicating the number of references that were found in all nine databases and imported into Covidence, the number of duplicates removed, the number of articles remained after title and abstract screening, and how many articles were included and excluded after the full-text screening phase. The reason for the exclusion of studies in the phase of full-text review will also be provided. The proforma used to extract data will be presented in a tabular format. 

Then, a narrative synthesis of the exacted data will be structured around marketing strategies, messages, and communication channels. Since certain messages may be more likely to be conveyed in certain types of marketing strategies and/or appear in certain types of communication channels, how marketing strategies, messages, and communication channels have interacted with each other will be analyzed.

q25.value:
Risk of bias (quality) assessment
The ideal checklist does not exist (Moja et al., 2005). In addition, most existing tools for quality assessment have been developed for randomized controlled trials or cohort or case control studies (Nagpal et al., 2010), which are not suitable for the studies included in this review. Therefore, we developed our own assessment criteria of the study quality. The checklist was based on The Cochrane Collaboration's tool for assessing risk of bias (2008, p. 195) and the six most commonly evaluated domains in quality and bias assessment identified by Sanderson et al. (2007) after reviewing 86 appraisal tools. Specifically, six domains were assessed in this study: (1) methods for sample selection, (2) methods for data collection, (3) methods for data analysis, (4) selective reporting, (5) conflict of interest, and (6) other sources of bias.
